query: What evidence exists for the effectiveness of different strategies to combat white-nose syndrome in bats?
relevant_summary: Evidence for the effectiveness of strategies to combat white-nose syndrome in bats is limited. Only probiotic bacterium treatment has been studied experimentally. Two randomized, controlled studies found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium increased survival in some contexts (within cages in a laboratory in Canada, and for free-flying bats in the USA), but had no significant effect on survival for caged bats in a mine. Disease symptoms were reduced when treatment occurred at the time of infection, but worsened when treatment was administered 21 days prior to infection. No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of other commonly proposed strategies, including breeding bats in captivity to supplement populations, treating hibernacula environments to reduce pathogen reservoirs, decontaminating clothing and equipment to prevent pathogen spread, or culling infected bats - meaning their effectiveness remains unassessed.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Survival (2 studies): One randomized, controlled study in Canada found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium at the time of infection with white-nose syndrome (but not 21 days prior) increased survival within cages in a laboratory. One randomized, controlled study in the USA found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium within a mine increased survival for free-flying bats, but not caged bats.
Condition (2 studies): One randomized, controlled study in Canada found that little brown bats caged in a laboratory and treated with a probiotic bacterium at the time of infection with white-nose syndrome had reduced symptoms of the disease, but bats treated 21 days prior to infection had worse symptoms. One randomized, controlled study in the USA found that little brown bats kept within cages in a mine and treated with a probiotic bacterium had a similar severity of white-nose syndrome to untreated bats.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

query: To mitigate the impact of road and railway developments, what structures can be installed to help bats cross safely?
relevant_summary: To help bats cross roads and railways safely, various structures can be installed including bat gantries or bat bridges (action ID 978), overpasses (action ID 977), green bridges (action ID 979), underpasses or culverts (action ID 976), and hop-overs (action ID 980). Evidence shows that green bridges were used by 97% of bats crossing a road in one UK study (action ID 979). However, bat gantries may be less effective, with studies finding that fewer bats used bat gantries than crossed the road below at traffic height, and some gantries were not used at all (action ID 978). Overpasses showed mixed results with some bat species using them but many still crossing the road below at traffic height or other locations (action ID 977). Underpasses and culverts were used by bats in varying proportions across multiple studies, with species adapted to cluttered habitats using smaller culverts more than those adapted to open habitats (action ID 976). There is currently no evidence available for hop-overs as no studies have evaluated their effectiveness (action ID 980).

query: To mitigate impacts from onshore wind farms, what are the most effective operational adjustments to turbines to reduce bat fatalities?
relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents shows several effective operational adjustments to reduce bat fatalities at onshore wind farms. Increasing the wind speed at which turbines become operational ('cut-in speed') was the most extensively studied approach, with 10 of 12 replicated studies in the USA and Canada finding this resulted in fewer bat fatalities (Action 1960). Preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds through 'feathering' also proved effective, with five of six studies showing reduced bat fatalities (Action 970). Automatically reducing turbine blade rotation when bat activity is predicted to be high was effective in both German and US studies, significantly reducing fatalities for all bat species combined and for individual species (Action 971). Slowing turbine blade rotation at low wind speeds was found to reduce bat fatalities in a Canadian study (Action 2939). Ultrasonic deterrents showed mixed results, with some studies finding 21-51% fewer bat fatalities in the first year, but inconsistent results in subsequent years and across different bat species (Action 968). No studies were found evaluating the effects of removing turbine lighting on bat fatalities (Action 969).

Survival (6 studies): Five of six studies (including five replicated, controlled studies and one before-and-after study) in the USA and Canada found that preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds (‘feathering’), or feathering along with increasing the wind speed at which turbines become operational (‘cut-in speed’) resulted in fewer bat fatalities than at conventionally operated turbines. POPULATION RESPONSE (12 STUDIES)

Survival (12 studies): Ten of 12 studies (including 10 replicated, randomized, controlled studies and one before-and-after study) in the USA and Canada found that increasing the wind speed at which turbines become operational (‘cut-in speed’), or increasing the cut-in speed along with preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds (‘feathering’) resulted in fewer bat fatalities than at conventionally operated turbines. The other two studies found that increasing cut-in speeds did not reduce bat fatalities, but sample sizes were small or treatments were applied for short periods only.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)

Survival (2 studies): Two replicated studies (one randomized, controlled and one paired sites study) in Germany and the USA found that automatically reducing the rotation speed of wind turbine blades when bat activity is predicted to be high resulted in fewer bat fatalities for all bat species combined and for five bat species.

Survival (3 studies): Three replicated, randomized, controlled studies (one with a before-and-after trial in the second year) in the USA found mixed results. In the first year of one study, 21-51% fewer bats were killed at turbines with an ultrasonic deterrent fitted than at control turbines, but in the second year, from 2% more to 64% fewer bats were killed at turbines with ultrasonic deterrents fitted. One study found that using an ultrasonic deterrent emitting a constant or pulsed signal had mixed effects on the fatality rates of three bat species. One study found that using ultrasonic deterrents resulted in fewer fatalities for two of three bat species.

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

Behaviour change (1 study): One paired sites study in the USA found fewer bats flying near one of two wind turbines with an ultrasonic deterrent compared to turbines without, but the effect of the deterrent overall was not significant."
}

query: How effective are different public education and engagement strategies for improving bat conservation outcomes?
relevant_summary: Evidence regarding the effectiveness of public education and engagement strategies for bat conservation is limited. No studies were found that evaluated educating the public to improve bat perception and behavior (action 1000), or educating farmers, land managers and communities about bat benefits for habitat management (action 2040). However, one UK study on engaging farmers and landowners to manage land for bats (action 1936) showed promising results: during a five-year project, the overall population of greater horseshoe bats at four maternity roosts increased, and 77 bat-related management agreements covering approximately 6,536 ha of land were established. Regarding general public awareness campaigns (action 162), a review of programs in the USA and Canada argued that education alone was not sufficient to change behavior, although it served as a necessary catalytic factor for economic incentives and law enforcement. While education campaigns for other wildlife groups (reptiles) have shown measurable conservation benefits including increased abundance (Philippine crocodiles), reduced poaching (leatherback turtle nests), and decreased human-caused mortality (Philippine crocodiles), similar evidence is lacking specifically for bat conservation initiatives.

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

Change in human behaviour (1 study): One study in the UK found that a landowner engagement project resulted in 77 bat-related management agreements covering approximately 6,536 ha of land."

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Abundance (1 studies): One before-and-after study in the Philippines found that following a communication, education, and public awareness campaign, the population of Philippine crocodiles increased.
Reproductive success (1 study): One study in Costa Rica found that during a community-based education programme the percentage of leatherback turtle nests lost to poaching decreased.
Survival (3 studies): Two before-and-after studies in the Philippines and Dominica found that following education and awareness campaigns, one in combination with use of road signs, human killing of Philippine crocodiles decreased and there were fewer road-deaths of lesser Antillean iguanas compared to before the campaigns began. One study in India reported that following education and awareness campaigns in combination with creating a network of local snake experts, local snake experts reported that they intervened to save 276 non-venomous snakes from being killed over six years.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (5 STUDIES)

Human behaviour change (3 studies): One replicated study in Colombia found that in areas with conservation initiatives relating to turtles, more people reported changing consumption habitats and fewer people reported using turtles for food compared to in areas with no initiatives, however, stated rates of hunting, buying and selling of turtles remained similar. One study in Saint Kitts found that attending an educational summer camp on turtle conservation had mixed effects on reported behaviours in relation to sea turtles of attendees and their parents/guardians, and mixed effects on whether they took part in conservation activities after the camp. One study in the USA found that providing an information leaflet did not decrease the number of hotel rooms that left lights on at night compared to when no leaflet was provided."

query: Besides avoiding illumination entirely, what alternative lighting strategies can be used to minimize disturbance to bats?
relevant_summary: Besides avoiding illumination entirely, several alternative lighting strategies can minimize disturbance to bats. Red lighting has shown promise, with studies finding that red lighting resulted in higher activity for some bat species compared to white or green lighting, and more soprano pipistrelles emerged from roosts when lit with red light compared to white light (action IDs: 2021). Using ultraviolet filters on lights can also be beneficial, with one study finding that hedges lit with ultraviolet filtered lights had higher soprano pipistrelle activity than those lit with unfiltered light (action ID: 1020). Low intensity lighting is another strategy, with one controlled study in caves finding that low intensity white lights or red lights resulted in fewer bat flights than full white lighting (action ID: 1994). Directing lighting away from bat access points or habitats is recommended as a strategy, though no studies have yet evaluated its effectiveness (action ID: 2019). Using 'warm white' LED lights rather than 'cool' LED lights has been suggested as a potential strategy, though no studies have evaluated this approach (action ID: 2020).

query: To protect bats from the impacts of mining operations, what actions can be taken during and after mine closure and reclamation?
relevant_summary: Based on available evidence, several actions can be considered for protecting bats during and after mine closure and reclamation. One study found that modifying the microclimate of an abandoned mine by closing a man-made entrance resulted in a greater number of bats hibernating within the mine (Action ID: 1964). Another study showed that restoring bat foraging habitat at ex-quarry sites can increase bat activity, with gravel-sand pits having higher overall bat activity 10 years after restoration compared to before or during quarrying (Action ID: 2286). However, no studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of retaining bat access points following mine closures, excluding bats from roosts prior to mine reclamation, or retaining access points to caves (Action IDs: 1962, 1961, 1990), meaning their effectiveness remains unassessed in the scientific literature.

query: What are the most effective legislative actions for protecting bats and their habitats?
relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, legally protecting bat habitats (action ID 2045) is the most documented legislative action for bat conservation. Five studies evaluated this approach and found positive effects on bat populations, with higher bat activity and abundance observed in protected areas compared to unprotected areas across Europe and India. One study found that 10 of 11 bat species distributions significantly overlapped with designated protection areas. However, no studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of other legislative measures such as legally protecting bat species, enforcing existing habitat protection legislation, controlling bat hunting through legislation, regulating bat guano harvesting, or enforcing anti-trafficking regulations.

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Five studies evaluated the effects of legally protecting bat habitats on bat populations. Four studies were in Europe and one was in India.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in India found that the composition of bat species was similar in protected forest and unprotected forest fragments.
Richness/diversity (2 studies): Two replicated, site comparison or paired sites studies in Europe and India found that the number of bat species did not differ between protected and unprotected forests or forest fragments. One replicated, site comparison study in France found that protected sites had a greater number of bat species than unprotected sites.

POPULATION RESPONSE (4 STUDIES)

Abundance (4 studies): One replicated, site comparison study in the UK found that the activity (relative abundance) of Daubenton’s bats was higher over rivers on farms in protected areas than in unprotected areas. One replicated, paired sites study in Europe found that the activity of common noctule bats was higher in protected forests than unprotected forests, but bat activity overall did not differ. Two replicated, site comparison studies in France and India found higher overall bat activity, higher activity of three of six bat species/species groups and a greater number of bats in protected sites and forests than unprotected sites and forests.

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)         

Use (1 study): One study in Spain found that the distributions of 10 of 11 bat species overlapped with areas designated to protect them significantly more than by chance."
}

query: For bat conservation related to transportation infrastructure, what are the documented benefits and limitations of providing or retaining roosts in bridges and culverts?
relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents shows mixed results for bat roost conservation in transportation infrastructure. For creating roost spaces in bridges, one review study found that spaces created to replace those lost during bridge works were recolonized by bats in similar or greater numbers at four of eight sites (Action ID: 1967). When maintaining existing roosts during bridge work, a before-and-after study in Ireland found that a Daubenton's bat maternity colony continued roosting in similar numbers after crevices were retained during repairs (Action ID: 1966). However, another review found that while Yuma myotis and Mexican free-tailed bats recolonised most maintained roosts in similar numbers, pallid bats did not return after bridge replacement works (Action ID: 1966). Providing alternative roosts showed poor results - bat houses provided during bridge replacement were used by fewer bats than original roosts at one site and not used at all at three sites (Action ID: 2942). No studies were found evaluating the effects of excluding bats from roosts during maintenance or changing the timing of maintenance work (Action IDs: 2941, 2940).

query: How does the evidence for managing existing hedgerows for bats compare to that for planting new ones?
relevant_summary: The evidence for managing existing hedgerows for bats significantly outweighs the evidence for planting new hedgerows. For existing hedgerow management, two UK studies evaluated managing hedges specifically for bats, finding that hedges trimmed ≥3 years prior had more bat species recorded and higher activity of two bat species compared to hedges trimmed during the previous winter (Action ID 1943). One study also found that up to one fifth of lesser horseshoe bats flew along an artificial hedgerow used to divert them to safe crossing points (Action ID 981). In contrast, for planting new hedgerows, one study found no evidence that planting new hedges has been evaluated for bats (Action ID 1942), and another found no studies evaluating creating new unlit bat commuting routes using planting (Action ID 2034). Similarly, no studies were found evaluating managing hedgerows to benefit wildlife on farmland in general (Action ID 2382). The evidence base is clearly weighted toward management of existing hedgerows rather than planting new ones.

query: What actions can be taken to provide bat roosting sites in trees where natural cavities are lacking?
relevant_summary:
Several actions can be taken to provide bat roosting sites in trees where natural cavities are lacking:

Creating artificial hollows and cracks in trees (Action 2047): One replicated study in Australia found that eight of 16 artificial hollows cut into trees with two different entrance designs were used by roosting long-eared bats.

Providing bat boxes (Action 1024): Forty-four studies found that bats used bat boxes installed in various habitats including forest, woodland, farmland, pasture, wetlands, and urban areas. A review of 109 studies found that 72 bat species used bat boxes, with 18 species commonly using them and 31 species using them as maternity roosts. Bat box design matters - studies found bats preferred black boxes over grey, white or wooden boxes, and occupancy varied with orientation, height, and position (on buildings vs trees).

Reinstating bat roosts in felled tree trunks (Action 2048): One before-and-after study in the UK found that a roost reinstated by attaching the felled tree trunk to a nearby tree continued to be used by common noctule bats as a maternity roost.

Creating alternative roosts within developments (Action 949): Eleven studies evaluated creating alternative bat roosts within developments. Some studies found bats used purpose-built roosts after original roosts were destroyed, while others found lower usage than the original roosts.

Providing bat boxes, bat grilles, and improvements to roosts (Action 95): No evidence was captured for the effects of these actions, indicating more research is needed.

Forty-four studies evaluated the effects of providing bat boxes for roosting bats on bat populations. Twenty-seven studies were in Europe, nine studies were in North America, four studies were in Australia, two studies were in South America, and one study was a worldwide review.

POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)

Uptake (9 studies): Nine replicated studies in Europe and the USA found that the number of bats using bat boxes increased by 2–10 times up to 10 years after installation.
Use (43 studies): Forty-one of 43 studies (including 34 replicated studies and two reviews) in Europe, the USA, South America, and Australia found that bats used bat boxes installed in forest or woodland, forestry plantations, farmland, pasture, wetlands, urban areas and buildings, bridges, underpasses or unknown habitats. The other two studies in the USA and UK found that bats displaced from buildings did not use any of 43 bat houses of four different designs or 12 heated bat boxes of one design. One review of 109 studies across Europe, North America and Asia found that 72 bat species used bat boxes, although only 18 species commonly used them, and 31 species used them as maternity roosts. Twenty-two studies (including 17 replicated studies, one before-and-after study and two reviews) found bats occupying less than half of bat boxes provided (0–49%). Nine replicated studies found bats occupying more than half of bat boxes provided (54–100%).

OTHER (23 STUDIES)

Bat box design (16 studies): Three studies in Germany, Portugal and Australia found that bats used black bat boxes more than grey, white or wooden boxes. One of two studies in Spain and the USA found higher occupancy rates in larger bat boxes. One study in the USA found that bats used both resin and wood cylindrical bat boxes, but another study in the USA found that resin bat boxes became occupied more quickly than wood boxes. One study in the UK found higher occupancy rates in concrete than wooden bat boxes. One study in the USA found that Indiana bats used rocket boxes more than wooden bat boxes or bark-mimic roosts. One study in Spain found that more bats occupied bat boxes that had two compartments than one compartment in the breeding season. One study in Lithuania found that bat breeding colonies occupied standard and four/five chamber bat boxes and individuals occupied flat bat boxes. Four studies in the USA, UK, Spain and Australia found bats selecting four of nine, three of five, three of four and one of five bat box designs. One study in the UK found that different bat box designs were used by different species. One study in Costa Rica found that bat boxes simulating tree trunks were used by 100% of bats and in group sizes similar to natural roosts.
Bat box position (11 studies): Three studies in Germany, Spain and the USA found that bat box orientation and/or the amount of exposure to sunlight affected bat occupancy, and one study in Spain found that orientation did not have a significant effect on occupancy. Two studies in the UK and Italy found that bat box height affected occupancy, and two studies in Spain and the USA found no effect of height. Two studies in the USA and Spain found higher occupancy of bat boxes on buildings than on trees. One study in Australia found that bat boxes were occupied more often in farm forestry sites than in native forest, one study in Poland found higher occupancy in pine relative to mixed deciduous stands, and one study in Costa Rica found higher occupancy in forest fragments than in pasture. One study in the USA found higher occupancy rates in areas where bats were known to roost prior to installing bat boxes. One review in the UK found that bat boxes were more likely to be occupied when a greater number of bat boxes were installed across a site."

query: How does the evidence for legally protecting bat habitats compare to legally protecting bats during development activities?
relevant_summary:
The evidence for legally protecting bat habitats shows more positive outcomes compared to legally protecting bats during development activities. For habitat protection (Action ID 2045), five studies found that legally protected sites had greater bat species richness and higher bat activity/abundance compared to unprotected sites. One study found that distributions of 10 of 11 bat species overlapped with protected areas significantly more than by chance.

In contrast, legal protection during development activities (Action ID 1935) showed more mixed results. Four UK studies found that while development licences for bats increased, 81% of licensees did not conduct required post-development monitoring. Licensed activities during building developments had negative impacts, with 68% of roosts being destroyed. Only 31-67% of compensation roosts provided under licence were used by bats, and new alternative roosts were four times less likely to be used than retained roosts. Retaining existing roosts and access points during development (Action ID 947) showed better outcomes, with two-thirds of retained roosts being used after development, and retained roosts were more likely to be used than newly created roosts.

query: In the agricultural sector, what are the observed effects of organic farming systems compared to conventional farming on bat populations?
relevant_summary: Twelve studies evaluated the effects of using organic farming instead of conventional farming on bat populations, with eight studies in Europe, two in the USA, one in Canada, and one in Chile. Community response was mixed: one study found no difference in bat species composition, while five of seven studies found no difference in species richness/diversity between organic and non-organic farms; the remaining two studies found more bat species on organic farms. Population response also varied: five of nine studies found no difference in overall bat activity or common pipistrelle activity, while four studies found higher overall bat activity, bat feeding activity, Brazilian free-tailed bat activity, and activity of four of seven bat species on organic farms. Two UK studies found higher activity of Myotis species over water and rivers on organic farms, and one French study found higher activity for two of three bat species over organic fields compared to conventionally managed fields.

query: During building developments, what alternatives to bat exclusion have been studied to mitigate disturbance to roosts?
relevant_summary: Studies have examined several alternatives to bat exclusion during building developments. Creating alternative bat roosts within developments has been tested in eleven studies, with mixed results - some studies found bats used purpose-built roosts in higher or similar numbers after original roosts were destroyed, while others found lower usage. Retaining existing bat roosts and access points during developments was examined in three studies and showed more consistent success, with retained roosts being used by similar or greater numbers of bats after development and being more likely to be used than newly created roosts. Relocating access points to roosts was tested in two studies with limited success, as bats showed reduced usage after access points were relocated. Providing bat boxes has been extensively studied in 44 studies overall, though their effectiveness for displaced bats is variable - while 41 of 43 studies found bats used bat boxes in various habitats including urban areas and buildings, two specific studies found bats displaced from buildings did not use provided bat houses or heated bat boxes.

query: What factors are associated with the successful use of artificial bat roosts by bats?
relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from action documents, several factors are associated with successful artificial bat roost use. Microclimate management is crucial, with one study showing increased bat numbers after artificial roosts were modified to reduce internal temperatures (action 2052). Bat boxes showed variable occupancy rates across 44 studies, with 31 species using them as maternity roosts, though only 18 species used them commonly (action 1024). Design factors significantly influence success: black bat boxes were used more than grey, white, or wooden alternatives (action 1024), and bats showed preferences for specific designs including multi-compartment boxes and concrete versus wooden materials. Position matters - bat box orientation and sunlight exposure affected occupancy, with boxes on buildings having higher occupancy than those on trees (action 1024). Height effects varied between studies, while location type influenced success, with farm forestry sites showing higher occupancy than native forest (action 1024). Artificial caves and hibernacula demonstrated gradual adoption, with one study showing increasing bat numbers over nine years after construction (action 2049). Success was enhanced when artificial roosts were installed in areas where bats were known to roost previously (action 1024). Tree hollow creation showed promise, with eight of 16 artificial tree hollows being used by long-eared bats (action 2047), suggesting that mimicking natural roost characteristics improves acceptance.

query: As an alternative to increasing turbine cut-in speeds, what other operational changes can reduce bat mortality at wind farms?
relevant_summary: Alternative operational changes to reduce bat mortality at wind farms include: preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds ('feathering'), which was found to reduce bat fatalities in five of six studies conducted in the USA and Canada; slowing the rotation of turbine blades at low wind speeds, which reduced bat fatalities in a Canadian study; automatically reducing turbine blade rotation when bat activity is predicted to be high, which resulted in fewer bat fatalities in studies conducted in Germany and the USA; using ultrasonic deterrents to deter bats from turbines, which showed mixed results with some studies finding fewer fatalities for certain bat species; and removing turbine lighting to reduce bat and insect attraction, though no studies have evaluated this method yet.

query: What conservation actions can be implemented to combat the spread and impact of white-nose syndrome in bats?
relevant_summary: Several conservation actions have been identified for combating white-nose syndrome in bats. The only action with scientific evidence is treating bats with probiotic bacteria, which showed increased survival in free-flying bats and reduced disease symptoms when administered at the time of infection in laboratory studies (Action ID: 2008). Other proposed actions include culling infected bats (Action ID: 1012), vaccinating bats against the pathogen (Action ID: 1011), breeding bats in captivity to supplement wild populations (Action ID: 2009), restricting human access to bat caves (Action ID: 1010), treating hibernacula environments to reduce pathogen reservoirs (Action ID: 2007), and decontaminating clothing and equipment after cave entry (Action ID: 2006). However, no scientific studies have evaluated the effectiveness of these latter actions.

query: What is the extent of evidence for actions to mitigate pollution from agricultural sources to benefit bats?
relevant_summary: The evidence base for actions to mitigate pollution from agricultural sources to benefit bats is currently extremely limited. No studies were found that evaluated the effects on bat populations of preventing pollution from agricultural land or forestry from entering watercourses (Action 2015), changing effluent treatments used in agriculture and forestry (Action 1016), planting riparian buffer strips (Action 2016), or managing ditches to benefit bats (Action 1944). One study evaluated retaining riparian buffers on agricultural land (Action 2284), finding no difference in pipistrelle activity between waterways with vegetation buffers on agri-environment scheme farms and conventional farms. This indicates that for the primary interventions aimed at reducing agricultural pollution - preventing agricultural runoff, modifying effluent treatments, and establishing vegetated buffers - there is currently no evidence demonstrating their effectiveness for bat conservation.

query: What design and placement factors influence the successful use of bat boxes by bats?
relevant_summary: Research on bat box effectiveness has identified several key design and placement factors that influence successful use by bats. Design factors include: color (black boxes used more than grey, white, or wooden boxes), size (larger bat boxes showed higher occupancy rates), material (concrete boxes had higher occupancy than wooden ones; resin boxes became occupied more quickly than wood), compartment configuration (two-compartment boxes occupied by more bats than one-compartment during breeding season), and specific design variants (rocket boxes preferred over wooden boxes or bark-mimic roosts by Indiana bats). Placement factors include: orientation and sun exposure (affects occupancy with orientation and sunlight amount being important), height (studies show mixed results with some finding height affects occupancy while others found no effect), location type (higher occupancy on buildings than trees in some studies), habitat context (farm forestry sites vs native forest, pine vs mixed deciduous stands), and prior bat presence (higher occupancy in areas where bats were known to roost before installing boxes). Additional factors include the number of boxes installed (greater numbers across a site increase occupancy likelihood) and microclimate management (modifying roost temperatures can increase bat numbers). However, 22 studies found bats occupying less than half of provided boxes (0-49%), while nine studies found occupancy rates above 50% (54-100%), indicating that even optimally designed and placed boxes may not always be used.

OTHER (23 STUDIES)

Bat box design (16 studies): Three studies in Germany, Portugal and Australia found that bats used black bat boxes more than grey, white or wooden boxes. One of two studies in Spain and the USA found higher occupancy rates in larger bat boxes. One study in the USA found that bats used both resin and wood cylindrical bat boxes, but another study in the USA found that resin bat boxes became occupied more quickly than wood boxes. One study in the UK found higher occupancy rates in concrete than wooden bat boxes. One study in the USA found that Indiana bats used rocket boxes more than wooden bat boxes or bark-mimic roosts. One study in Spain found that more bats occupied bat boxes that had two compartments than one compartment in the breeding season. One study in Lithuania found that bat breeding colonies occupied standard and four/five chamber bat boxes and individuals occupied flat bat boxes. Four studies in the USA, UK, Spain and Australia found bats selecting four of nine, three of five, three of four and one of five bat box designs. One study in the UK found that different bat box designs were used by different species. One study in Costa Rica found that bat boxes simulating tree trunks were used by 100% of bats and in group sizes similar to natural roosts.
Bat box position (11 studies): Three studies in Germany, Spain and the USA found that bat box orientation and/or the amount of exposure to sunlight affected bat occupancy, and one study in Spain found that orientation did not have a significant effect on occupancy. Two studies in the UK and Italy found that bat box height affected occupancy, and two studies in Spain and the USA found no effect of height. Two studies in the USA and Spain found higher occupancy of bat boxes on buildings than on trees. One study in Australia found that bat boxes were occupied more often in farm forestry sites than in native forest, one study in Poland found higher occupancy in pine relative to mixed deciduous stands, and one study in Costa Rica found higher occupancy in forest fragments than in pasture. One study in the USA found higher occupancy rates in areas where bats were known to roost prior to installing bat boxes. One review in the UK found that bat boxes were more likely to be occupied when a greater number of bat boxes were installed across a site."

query: How do different types of purpose-built road crossing structures compare in effectiveness for bats?
relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, different types of bat crossing structures show varying levels of effectiveness. Green bridges appear to be the most effective, with one study finding that a green bridge was used by 97% of bats crossing a road (Action ID 979). Underpasses and culverts have been studied most extensively, with eight studies showing that bats use them in varying proportions depending on factors such as underpass type, height, road width, and surrounding landscape features (Action ID 976). Bat species adapted to cluttered habitats used small culverts and underpasses more than species adapted to open or edge habitats. Overpasses show mixed results, with studies indicating that while some bat species use them, up to three-quarters of bats still cross the road below at traffic height or at other nearby locations - vegetated overpasses with planters were used by two-thirds of crossing bats, while unvegetated overpasses were not used at all (Action ID 977). Bat gantries or bat bridges appear to be the least effective, with studies finding that fewer bats used them than crossed the road below at traffic height, and some gantries were not used at all (Action ID 978). No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of hop-overs for bats (Action ID 980).

query: For arid regions, what is the evidence on the effectiveness of creating or managing water sources to support bat populations?
relevant_summary: Evidence from five studies shows that creating artificial water sources can be effective for supporting bat populations in arid regions. Five replicated studies across Israel, the USA, Germany, South Africa and Mexico found that bat activity (relative abundance) was similar or higher over reservoirs, waste water treatment pools, heliponds, drainage ditches, retention ponds and farm/cattle ponds compared to natural wetlands, vineyards, forest or grassland/crops (Action 959). For livestock water troughs specifically, two studies in the USA demonstrated that management matters - removing livestock modifications resulted in bats drinking more frequently and approaching troughs fewer times before successfully drinking (Action 1951). One study in Portugal found that small dam reservoirs created greater activity for four bat species than the streams feeding into them (Action 1997). However, no studies were found evaluating the effects of managing natural water bodies to prevent desiccation in arid areas (Action 2027), indicating a knowledge gap in this area.

query: In agricultural landscapes, which farming systems are most beneficial for bat populations?
relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from action documents, organic farming systems (action ID 961) show mixed but generally positive effects on bat populations. Twelve studies found that organic farming resulted in higher bat activity and species richness compared to conventional farming in some cases, with five of nine studies showing higher overall bat activity on organic farms. Agroforestry systems that retain or plant native trees and shrubs amongst crops (action ID 963) showed varied results across eight studies, with some finding higher bat species diversity and abundance in plantations with varied shade cover. Reducing pesticide, herbicide and fertiliser use (action ID 2013) demonstrated positive effects in four studies, with farms using fewer chemicals showing higher bat activity and species diversity. Managing hedges specifically for bats (action ID 1943) showed limited but positive effects in two UK studies, with hedges trimmed less frequently having more bat species and higher activity. However, there is currently no evidence available for several potentially beneficial practices including increasing semi-natural habitat (action ID 1938), retaining remnant forest (action ID 1947), managing ditches for bats (action ID 1944), practicing integrated farm management (action ID 169), or planting in-field trees (action ID 1946).

query: What are the outcomes and success rates associated with ex-situ bat conservation actions like captive breeding and rehabilitation?
relevant_summary: Based on action documents, eight studies evaluated captive breeding effects, showing that 6-100% of female bats captured in the wild successfully conceived, gave birth and reared young in captivity across studies in the USA, UK, Italy and Brazil. Two studies found that two of five and two of three bats born in captivity successfully gave birth to live young. Seven studies found that 20-100% of bat pups born in captivity survived from 10 days to adulthood. However, no studies evaluated the effects of releasing captive-bred bats back to the wild. Four studies evaluated rehabilitation of injured/orphaned bats. One study in Brazil found two hand-reared orphaned greater spear-nosed bats survived over three months in captivity and reached normal species size after 60 days. Two studies in the UK and Italy found 70-90% of hand-reared pipistrelle bats survived 4-14 days after wild release, with six of 21 bats joining wild colonies. One UK study found 13% of ringed hand-reared pipistrelle bats were found alive in bat boxes 38 days to four years after release. Another UK study found bats that flew in large flight cages for longer periods survived longer and were more active after release. Importantly, no studies evaluated breeding bats specifically to supplement wild populations affected by white-nose syndrome.

Two studies found that two of five and two of three bats born in captivity successfully gave birth to live young. Seven studies found that 20-100% of bat pups born in captivity survived from 10 days to adulthood. However, no studies evaluated the effects of releasing captive-bred bats back to the wild. Four studies evaluated rehabilitation of injured/orphaned bats. One study in Brazil found two hand-reared orphaned greater spear-nosed bats survived over three months in captivity and reached normal species size after 60 days. Two studies in the UK and Italy found 70-90% of hand-reared pipistrelle bats survived 4-14 days after wild release, with six of 21 bats joining wild colonies. One UK study found 13% of ringed hand-reared pipistrelle bats were found alive in bat boxes 38 days to four years after release. Another UK study found bats that flew in large flight cages for longer periods survived longer and were more active after release. Importantly, no studies evaluated breeding bats specifically to supplement wild populations affected by white-nose syndrome.", "action_ids": ["2053", "2054", "2009", "2039"], "query": "What are the outcomes and success rates associated with ex-situ bat conservation actions like captive breeding and rehabilitation?"}
